Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Situation2: A holiday travel surge fills the approach fixes with moderate holding delays.
Story: My phone buzzes on the console, lighting up with a message from Alex: “I thought we were going to your parents’ this weekend, not mine?” I can almost hear the disappointment in her words. I want to reply, to clear up the mix-up before it festers, but my headset crackles with the clipped voices of pilots. The radar screen is a mess—holiday traffic has the approach stacked with holding patterns, and I’m juggling clearances, calculating fuel, and keeping a mental map of every aircraft in my sector. My supervisor expects flawless coordination; one mistake could ripple through the entire system. But Alex expects me to be present, to resolve things before they become real problems. My fingers hover over my phone, heart pounding, torn between the urgent demands of the airspace and the fragile peace of my relationship. I can’t do both at once, and the weight of choosing presses down on me, harder with every passing second.
